description: From New Latin sudorificus, from sūdor (“sweat”) (from Proto-Indo-European *sweyd- (“sweat; to sweat”)) + -ificus (from Proto-Italic *-fakos (“suffix forming adjectives that denote bringing or making”), ultimately related to Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to do, put, place”)).

adjectives.description: sudorific (comparative more sudorific, superlative most sudorific)

entries.meaning: In a state of perspiration; covered in sweat; sudoriferous, sweaty.
(chiefly pharmacology) That produces sweating. [from early 17th c.]
